item.description:
• Over the last few years, research has shown that having too much visceral fat can be very harmful to a person’s health.
  • Past studies have shown that having an unhealthy amount of visceral fat may increase a person’s risk of several health conditions.
  • A new study found that improving both diet and exercise levels simultaneously may be more effective in preventing weight gain, particularly of visceral fat.

Over the last few years, research has shown that having excessive visceral fat — the fat surrounding the abdominal area that protects internal organs — can be detrimental to a person’s health.

“Abdominal weight gain is a major public health concern,” Shayan Aryannezhad, MD, MPH, PhD, doctoral graduate of the MRC Epidemiology Unit at the University of Cambridge, and clinical research fellow at the Nuffield Department of Population Health at the University of Oxford, in the United Kingdom, told Medical News Today.

“Nearly 3 billion people worldwide are living with overweight or obesity. Weight gain usually happens slowly, over many years, and we still have limited evidence on how everyday behaviors can help prevent the build-up of fat in different body compartments over the long term. Fat that builds up deep in the abdomen around internal organs, known as visceral fat, is especially harmful. It raises the risk of cardiometabolic diseases and premature death. Finding effective ways to prevent this type of fat gain is therefore very important.”

— Shayan Aryannezhad, MD, MPH, PhD

Aryannezhad is the first author of a new study published in the journal JAMA Network Open, which found that improving both diet and exercise levels at the same time may be more helpful in preventing weight gain, especially of visceral fat, than focusing on only one of those healthy lifestyle choices.

For this study, researchers analyzed the health data of more than 7,000 study participants in the U.K.-based Fenland study.

Study participants were at an average age of about 49 at the start of the Fenland study, which followed participants for an average of 7 years.

Participant follow-up included measuring physical activity energy expenditure for at least 72 hours, a DEXA scan to assess body fat, and an evaluation of participants’ adherence to the Mediterranean diet.

“Most long-term studies look at diet and physical activity separately, but people do not live their lives in isolated behaviors,” Aryannezhad said. “Evidence shows that clearer and more consistent links with health outcomes appear when we assess changes in both behaviors at the same time.”

“This may be because people often make compensatory changes,” he added. “For example, becoming more active may lead someone to eat more, or vice versa. Studying the behaviors together gives a more realistic understanding of how they influence long-term adiposity.”

At the study’s conclusion, researchers found that participants who simultaneously improved their diet and physical activity levels had the highest reduction in body fat, while changing only one of those lifestyle choices was linked to moderate body fat improvements.

Scientists also discovered that after adjusting for body mass index (BMI), the correlation of diet and physical activity changes resulted in significant changes to visceral fat levels, showing that visceral fat was specifically responsive to these healthy changes.

Researchers reported that participants who improved diet and exercise at the same time increased on average about 1.9 kilograms (kg) less total body fat and 150 grams (g) less visceral fat than those who did not make both lifestyle improvements.

“This is a meaningful difference,” Aryannezhad explained. “Gaining 1.9 kg less total body fat represents about 7% of the average body fat in this population.“

“Previous research shows that around 10% increase in body fat is associated with an 11% higher risk of all-cause mortality. The additional 150 g less visceral fat is also important, as visceral fat is the most harmful type. This is approximately 16% of (the) total visceral fat of this population,” he emphasized.

“Improving both diet quality and physical activity was linked not only with less weight gain, but also with a healthier pattern of body fat distribution,” Aryannezhad continued. “Addressing both behaviors together appears to offer greater benefits than improving either one alone. These health behaviors should be seen as complementary strategies, not competing ones.”

MNT spoke with Mir Ali, MD, a board certified general surgeon, bariatric surgeon, and medical director of MemorialCare Surgical Weight Loss Center at Orange Coast Medical Center in Fountain Valley, CA, about this study.

Ali, who was not involved in the research, commented that he thought this was a good study that showed the benefits of combining exercise and a healthy diet.

“Visceral fat (around the abdomen) has been shown to increase the risk of diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and many other conditions,” he explained.

“Any method that can reduce visceral fat is beneficial to the patient,“ said Ali. “More research into defining the optimal diets and exercises to eliminate and maintain visceral fat loss would be helpful.”

MNT also spoke with Seth Kipnis, MD, FACS, FASMBS, director of bariatric and robotic surgery at Hackensack Meridian Jersey Shore University Medical Center in New Jersey, about this research, who said that this study provides evidence for the advice he gives to his patients every day.

“Often, patients come frustrated, having tried to focus on just diet or just exercise without seeing the results they want, especially around their midsection,” Kipnis, who was not involved in the research, explained. “This study demonstrates that the combination of improving diet quality and increasing physical activity is the most effective strategy.”

“What’s particularly compelling is the use of advanced imaging like DEXA scans to differentiate between types of fat. I frequently explain to patients that the ‘belly fat’ we are most concerned about isn’t the fat you can pinch (subcutaneous fat), but the deeper visceral fat surrounding their organs. This study’s finding that a combined approach is especially effective at reducing this dangerous visceral fat. It is not just about the number on the scale but the overall body composition.”

— Seth Kipnis, MD, FACS, FASMBS

“The finding that individuals who were overweight or inactive at the start of the study saw the greatest benefits is also very encouraging,” Kipnis added. “It provides a hopeful and motivating message for the very patients who often feel the most discouraged.”

Five Effective Ways to Detoxify Your Gut Health

Fatty liver grows in silence. Many people feel fine on the outside while small changes inside the body keep building. Dr Saurabh Sethi, a Harvard-trained gastroenterologist, explains that the liver sends out signals before serious damage sets in. These signs may feel easy to brush off, but they tell a story about how the liver is struggling to handle fat, sugar and inflammation. Each clue deserves attention because early action can still protect the organ that works every hour without rest. Take a look

Sudden belly weight that feels “different”

Unexpected weight gain around the abdomen appears before any other symptom. It is not the usual bloating from a heavy meal. The fat settles deep under the skin and around the organs, which makes the waist feel firm rather than soft. This shift suggests that the liver is storing more fat than it can process. Fatty liver diet: Best and worst foods for your liver

Rising blood sugar despite no diet change

A healthy liver helps regulate blood sugar. When it becomes fatty, this control weakens. The result is higher sugar readings even when meals stay the same. Some people notice that they feel hungry soon after eating or feel sleepy after simple meals.

Urine that turns darker and stools that lose colour

Dark urine and pale stools do not always come from dehydration or a mild stomach bug. When the liver struggles to produce and move bile, colour changes show up in the bathroom. These changes act as early hints that bile flow is getting disrupted, a process that needs medical attention before the condition progresses. Left unchecked, these subtle signs can gradually escalate into more serious symptoms as the underlying issue worsens.

A slow fade of energy

Fatigue from fatty liver feels different from everyday tiredness. It creeps in early in the day, even after a good sleep. Muscles feel heavier, and simple tasks need more effort. Doctors believe the liver’s reduced ability to clear toxins and regulate energy pathways plays a key role in this deep, persistent weakness.

A tight, dull ache in the upper abdomen

A mild but recurring discomfort under the right rib cage is a classic clue. It is not sharp like gallstone pain and not cramp-like. Instead, it feels like a tightness or pressure that comes and goes. This suggests that the liver is enlarged or inflamed, which often happens when fat begins to collect inside its cells.

Cholesterol numbers that climb without warning

When the liver turns fatty, it struggles to manage fats in the bloodstream. LDL creeps up, HDL drops, and triglycerides climb higher than expected. These quiet biochemical shifts usually appear on routine tests long before any visible symptoms. They are among the most reliable early indicators of liver stress.

Yellowing of the eyes: a late and urgent sign

Jaundice usually means the disease has advanced. The whites of the eyes gain a yellow tint, and the skin may follow. This happens when bilirubin builds up in the blood because the liver cannot process it well. At this stage, quick medical care becomes essential to prevent further complications.

Easy bruising and unexpected bleeding

Bruises that form from simple bumps and gums that bleed more during brushing suggest that the liver’s ability to produce clotting factors is weakening. These signs rarely occur early. They point toward a more serious stage where the liver’s core functions are affected.

item.description:
Oversleeping, defined as sleeping nine or more hours in 24 hours, can seem harmless, especially after a tiring week, but consistently sleeping too much often signals that something deeper is affecting your health. While sleep is essential for restoring energy, supporting immunity, and maintaining cognitive function, excessive sleep can leave you feeling groggy, unfocused, and unusually tired during the day. Many people who oversleep also experience headaches, low motivation, or the need for frequent naps, showing that the body may not be getting truly restorative rest. Oversleeping can be influenced by lifestyle habits, environmental disruptions, medical conditions, mental health issues, medications, or underlying sleep disorders. Understanding why you’re sleeping too much is the first step toward improving sleep quality, boosting daytime energy, and restoring a healthier sleep routine.

7 common causes of excessive sleep and daytime tiredness

Drug and alcohol use

Certain substances directly interfere with the brain chemicals responsible for alertness. When someone stops using stimulants like amphetamines or cocaine, the body enters a “rebound” phase. During this phase, the nervous system slows down to recover, creating intense sleepiness and longer sleep durations. A

study published in PubMed Central

found that alcohol reduces restorative REM sleep and disrupts sleep architecture, leading to poor-quality rest, morning fatigue, and increased daytime sleepiness.

Fix Your Sleep Naturally! Sadhguru’s 5-Step Routine for Deep Rest

Alcohol also has a complicated effect on sleep. It may help you fall asleep faster, but it reduces deep and REM sleep, the stages that restore energy and cognitive function. As a result, people often wake feeling unrefreshed and may sleep longer to compensate. Chronic alcohol use can disrupt brain signalling and worsen daytime tiredness, leading to unintentional dozing and difficulty staying awake.

Environmental factors affecting sleep duration

Your environment and daily responsibilities can push your sleep schedule out of balance. For example, people caring for infants, older adults, or sick family members often get fragmented or insufficient sleep, causing their bodies to demand longer rest when possible.

Irregular routines such as late-night screen use, long work hours, or inconsistent bedtimes can confuse the body’s internal clock. Shift workers are especially affected because their sleep occurs at times when the brain naturally expects light or activity. This mismatch between work demands and biological rhythms can lead to chronic fatigue and oversleeping on off-days as the body tries to recover. Over time, this disruption may also increase stress, weaken immunity, affect mood, and impair cognitive function, making it harder to maintain consistent energy levels and overall health despite attempts to rest.

Illnesses that cause prolonged sleep

When you are sick, the immune system releases chemicals called cytokines that increase sleepiness to help the body heal. This is why respiratory infections such as flu, colds, or COVID-19 often make you sleep more than usual. However, even long hours of sleep during illness may not feel refreshing because the body is directing energy toward fighting infection. Fever, inflammation, and general weakness raise the need for rest, so extra sleep becomes the body’s natural response to promote recovery.

Lack of sleep and sleep debt

Sleep debt builds up when you consistently get less sleep than your body needs. Whether due to long workdays, late-night studying, travel, or stress, the body eventually reaches a point where it demands extra sleep to restore balance.

While catching up on sleep can temporarily relieve exhaustion, it can also disrupt your sleep cycle if done frequently. Oversleeping after sleep deprivation may lead to irregular bedtimes, low morning energy, and difficulty falling asleep the next night, creating an ongoing cycle of poor sleep quality.

Medications that lead to excessive sleep

Many medications contain compounds that slow down brain activity or nervous system responses. Antihistamines, for example, block alertness-related receptors, while some antidepressants and antipsychotics reduce brain stimulation, making you feel more tired. Pain medications, muscle relaxants, tranquillisers, and sleeping pills can also deepen or lengthen sleep beyond normal needs. A

study published in Published in PubMed Central

concluded that many antidepressant medications alter sleep architecture, some with sedative effects that can prolong sleep or cause excessive daytime drowsiness. If you notice increased sleepiness after starting a new medication, it may indicate that your body is sensitive to its sedative effects, and a doctor can help adjust the dose or suggest alternatives.

Physical and mental health conditions linked to oversleeping

Oversleeping can be an early sign of underlying health conditions. Disorders like hypothyroidism slow down metabolism, causing fatigue and the need for more sleep. Diabetes, fibromyalgia, chronic pain, and chronic fatigue syndrome strain the body and reduce energy levels, making longer sleep periods common.

Mental health conditions, especially depression, can significantly alter sleep patterns. Depression often leads to hypersomnia, where people sleep long hours but still feel exhausted because emotional stress interferes with restorative sleep. Anxiety can cause mental burnout and tension, which may lead to oversleeping as the body tries to cope.

Sleep disorders that cause excessive sleep

Certain sleep disorders directly affect how long and how well you sleep:

  • Circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorders: These develop when your internal body clock falls out of sync with natural light-dark cycles. As a result, you may sleep at irregular times, struggle to wake up, or feel the need to oversleep to cope with the mismatch.
  • Hypersomnolence disorder (hypersomnia): This condition causes persistent daytime sleepiness even after a full night’s sleep. People with hypersomnia often sleep much longer than usual, yet still wake up feeling unrefreshed.
  • Narcolepsy: This neurological disorder leads to sudden and uncontrollable episodes of falling asleep during the day. These “sleep attacks” can happen during routine activities, making daytime functioning difficult.
  • Obstructive sleep apnoea: This condition repeatedly blocks or restricts airflow during sleep, causing brief awakenings and poor sleep quality. The constant disruption leads to extreme fatigue and a tendency to oversleep.
  • Restless leg syndrome: This disorder creates uncomfortable, tingling, or creeping sensations in the legs, especially at night. Because it interrupts sleep, the body tries to compensate with longer sleep periods or daytime sleepiness.

Because these conditions affect sleep structure, the brain does not get the deep, restorative rest it needs, resulting in prolonged sleep times. Oversleeping is more than just sleeping late; it can signal an imbalance in the body, lifestyle, or overall sleep health. By understanding the underlying causes, whether environmental, medical, psychological, or behavioural, you can take steps to improve energy levels and restore healthy sleep patterns. If oversleeping persists or disrupts your daily life, consulting a healthcare professional can help identify and treat the root cause, leading to more balanced and restorative sleep
